Review Photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones Kai Sun a † Fang Xiao b a Bing Yu a * Wei-Min He c # a Green Catalysis Center, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China Green Catalysis Center College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou Henan 450001 China Green Catalysis Center, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China b Xiangya School of Public Health, Central South University, Changsha 410078, Hunan, China Xiangya School of Public Health Central South University Changsha Hunan 410078 China Xiangya School of Public Health, Central South University, Changsha 410078, Hunan, China c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of South China, Hengyang 421001, Hunan, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering University of South China Hengyang Hunan 421001 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of South China, Hengyang 421001, Hunan, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author † Contributed equally to this work. The photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones has emerged as a promising and powerful approach for post-synthetic modification of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. This review provides an overview of recent developments in photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones including arylation, alkylation, fluoroalkylation, amination, phosphorylation, acylation, alkoxylation, thiolation, silylation, and annulation. The reaction scope and the related mechanism are also well discussed. Graphical abstract The photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones has emerged as a promising and powerful approach for the post-synthetic modification of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. This review provides an overview of recent developments in the photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. Keywords Photocatalysis Electrocatalysis Quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones C–H functionalization 1 Introduction Quinoxalin-2(1H)-one, an important N-heterocycle scaffold, has gained significant attention in the recent years. The quinoxalin-2(1H)-one moiety is extensively encountered in antimicrobial compounds, antitumor agents, semiconductors, etc. [1–5]. Therefore, it is highly important in the preparation of various quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. In recent years, numerous procedures have been reported as powerful methods for obtaining quinoxalin-2(1H)-one derivatives [6–11]. Among them, the direct C–H functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-one is one of the most powerful and convenient strategies. Although some excellent reviews have been published to summarize the advances in this field [12–15], recent progress has not been included. Additionally, technologies such as photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, and photoelectrocatalysis have emerged as robust and sustainable tools in modern organic synthesis [16–29]. In the past two years, the importance of photocatalytic or electrocatalytic strategies to access different functionalized quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones has been witnessed. A detailed summary of this field is of significance and highly desired, but there is currently no comprehensive review. Considering this, this review summarizes the most recent progress (mainly from 2018) in the photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones, which include 3-arylation, 3-alkylation, 3-fluoroalkylation, 3-alkoxylation, 3-acylation, 3-amination, 3-phosphorylation, 3-thiolation, 3-silylation, and annulation reactions. In particular, the newly developed reaction types are especially important, as they will facilitate the understanding of C–H functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones and further stimulate the development of more novel relevant strategies. 2 Photo- and electrocatalytic transformations 2.1 3-Arylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 3-Arylquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones are of significance in biological and medicinal chemistry, as they show promising antibacterial and anticancer activities [30]. Arylation reactions are one of the most commonly used synthetic strategies in organic synthesis to introduce aryl- or heteroaryl-moieties into organic molecular skeletons, and are commonly employed as essential steps for the preparation of natural products, drugs, or functional materials. Numerous transition-metal-catalyzed cross-coupling and C−H arylation methods have been developed. Despite the great advancements, transition-metal catalysts, specific ligands/additives, and elevated temperatures are usually required in these transformations. In 2015, the Chupakhin group reported the TiO2-catalyzed cross-coupling reaction of quinoxalin-2(1H)-one 1a with indoles or pyrrole 1b to access 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 1c under irradiation by a Xe lamp (35 W) (Scheme 1 ) [31]. Some other azaaromatic systems, including mono-, di-, and triazines, could also be employed as suitable substrates. The proposed mechanism showed that the reversible protonation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones with AcOH generated intermediate 1d, which subsequently underwent reversible nucleophilic addition with indoles or pyrrole 1b to afford σH-adducts 1e. Finally, intermediate 1e regenerated the aromatic system to access 3-arylquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 1c in the presence of TiO2 and O2 along with the formation of H2O2. Aryl diazonium salts are a significant class of arylating agents that have attracted increasing interest in the past decades as aryl radical precursors. After the pioneering study of the [Ru(bpy)3]2+-catalyzed Pschorr reaction reported by Cano-Yelo et al. [32] 30 years ago, aryl diazonium salts have been widely applied in various photocatalyzed organic transformations because of their relatively high reduction potential. In 2018, the Wei’s group reported a direct method for the 3-arylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones using aryl diazonium salts as aryl radical precursors with 3 W blue LED irradiation in air (Scheme 2 ) [33]. This elegant protocol showed a wide reaction scope and good functional group tolerance. Aryl diazonium salts 2b with attached electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups are all suitable for this green and sustainable transformation, affording the 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 2c in satisfactory yields. A significant effect of steric hindrance on the reaction efficiency has been discovered in these cases, and ortho-methyl substituted phenyl diazonium salts showed poorer reactivity, leading to the formation of the corresponding product in lower yield than para- or meta-methyl phenyl diazonium salts. Furthermore, numerous quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 2a were viable to produce 2c. Moreover, allyl and propargyl groups could be retained well. Additionally, non-substituted quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones were also suitable substrates to access products 2c in moderate yields. Radical trapping experiments performed by adding a radical scavenger (TEMPO, 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy) to the standard systems severely inhibited this transformation, suggesting that a radical process should be involved in this transformation. It was postulated that Eosin Y was transformed into excited-state Eosin Y* to react with aryl diazonium salts 2b for the generation of aryl radical 2d via a single electron transfer (SET) process. Next, the addition of 2d to the C-3 position of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 2a afforded radical intermediate 2e. Radical 2e was further oxidized by Eosin Y•+ to access nitrogen cation 2f along with the regeneration of Eosin Y for the next cycle. However, the oxidation of radical intermediate 2e by O2 could not be ruled out. Finally, intermediate 2f transformed into the final products 2c by regenerating the aromatic system via deprotonation. At almost the same time, the Kim group disclosed a similar strategy for the preparation of 3-aryl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones by employing aryl diazonium salts as the aryl radical precursors in dimethyl sulfoxide [34]. Despite the great achievements, however, Eosin Y is hard to separate for reuse. In recent years, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have emerged as promising heterogeneous photocatalysts with the advantages of easy catalyst recyclability, high chemical stability, remarkably tunable photocatalytic properties, and large surface areas. In 2020, Yang et al. [35] disclosed a practical and straightforward strategy for the arylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones by employing a two-dimensional covalent organic framework (2D-COF-1) as a sustainable photocatalyst (Scheme 3 ). The corresponding 3-aryl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 3c reported in Wei [33] and Kim’s methods [34] could be smoothly prepared using this powerful catalytic system. Moreover, 3-alkyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 3c could also be isolated in good yields by employing alkyl hydrazines as alkyl radical precursors. Tert-butyl hydrazine hydrochloride showed better alkylation efficiency, which allowed the generation of 3-tert-butyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones in higher yields than primary and secondary alkyl hydrazine hydrochlorides. This sustainable method was easy to scale up, and thus displayed promising prospects for industrial applications. Moreover, the heterogeneous 2D-COF-1 could be easily recycled for at least six runs without obvious loss of photocatalytic activity. The control experiment performed under an argon atmosphere did not yield the desired product, implying the necessity of oxygen. The suppression of the transformation and the TEMPO adducts detected by GC-MS when TEMPO was injected into the reaction mixture indicated the presence of a radical mechanism for this strategy. Moreover, the radical-chain process could be excluded in this process due to the low value of the apparent quantum efficiency. The mechanism indicated that the excited-state 2D-COF-1* could be oxidized by O2 to form 2D-COF-1+ along with the formation of O2 •−. In the presence of O2 •−, hydrazine 3b was converted into radical 3d, which subsequently added to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 3a to afford 3e. Radical 3e then underwent a 1,2-H shift to give carbon-centered radical 3f, which further reacted with 2D-COF-1+ to yield intermediate 3g. Finally, the intermediate 3g lost a proton to regenerate the aromatic system, affording the product 3c. The photocatalytic 3-arylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones without a photocatalyst is undoubtedly very attractive. Very recently, the Li group and He group reported a photocatalyst-free strategy for the arylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 4a (Scheme 4 ) [36,37]. A large variety of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 4a and aryl acyl peroxides 4b were investigated, and the corresponding products 4c could be obtained in acceptable yields, showing wide substrate applicability and good functional group tolerance. Moreover, 2H-benzo[b][1,4]oxazin-2-one was also a suitable substrate for this process to obtain the desired product in moderate yield. This simple protocol was easily scaled up, and 1.08 g of 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-one was isolated in 61% yield by scaling up the model reaction to 7.5 mmol. Additionally, this photocatalyst-free method was applicable to access an antitumor agent. The mechanistic studies, including radical trapping experiments and electron spin resonance spectroscopy (ESR) experiments, gave direct evidence of the involvement of a radical process. The proposed mechanism showed that the quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones were the photocatalysts and could absorb light energy to access the excited-state 4a* or 4c*. Then, the energy transfer (EnT) process between aryl acyl peroxide 4b and 4a* or 4c* produced benzoyloxyl radicals 4d, which further underwent decarboxylation to afford aryl radicals 4e along with the release of CO2 and regeneration of ground-state 4a or 4c. After selective radical addition, radical 4f was generated, which finally produced the desired products 4c by reaction with radical 4d. In 2021, a simple procedure for the photosynthesis of 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 5c was developed by utilizing arylboronic acids 5b as arylation reagents and K2S2O8 as the oxidant (Scheme 5 ) [38]. The employment of H2O as the solvent might be beneficial to enhance the solubility of phenylboronic acids 5b and K2S2O8 to provide good reactivity. A control experiment involving the addition of TEMPO to the standard reaction system indicated the presence of a radical pathway. The reaction between K2S2O8 and Eosin Y* would generate radical 5d, which further reacted with boronic acid 5b to access aryl radical 5e. Afterward, aryl radical 5e added to the quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones to afford nitrogen radical 5f, followed by a 1,2-H shift to produce carbon radical 5g. The oxidation of carbon radical 5g by Eosin Y•+ generated carbon cation 5h, which finally underwent deprotonation to provide 5c. In 2019, Zeng and co-workers [39] disclosed the electrosynthesis of 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 6c by employing aryldiazonium salt 6b as an arylating agent (Scheme 6 ). The mechanistic studies showed that aryl diazonium salt 6b was initially reduced to phenyl diazo radical 6d at the surface of the cathode, which subsequently lost an N2 molecule to produce aryl radical 6e. Afterward, aryl radical 6e was added to the quinoxalin-2(1H)-one to give radical intermediate 6f. Subsequently, radical intermediate 6f was further oxidized at the anode leading to the formation of 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-one 6c (pathway 1). Additionally, homogeneous electron transfer in solution between radical intermediate 6f and the aryldiazonium salts 6b could also yield the desired products 6c along with the formation of phenyl diazo radicals 6d (pathway 2). This radical chain process indicated that only a catalytic amount of charge was required for the current protocol. Very recently, the Wen’s group disclosed a powerful method for the pyridylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 7c (Scheme 7 ) [40]. The control experiments and 1H NMR analysis indicated that cyanopyridine was more easily protonated with hexafluoroisopropanol (HFIP) to produce pyridinium, rendering cyanopyridine more conducive to electroreduction. More impressively, various non-pyridine derivatives were also applicable to afford bidentate nitrogen ligand products. Very recently, the Wang’s group reported the electro-oxidative azolation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones under metal-, oxidant-, and reagent-free conditions (Scheme 8 ) [41]. Importantly, this efficient strategy could be implemented using pencil lead as an electrode and a 3 V battery as a power source without complex equipment. The mechanism showed that pyrazoles 8b were oxidized at the anode to form the nitrogen radical 8d, which was further added to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 8a to produce radical 8e. Radical 8e was then oxidized at the anode to generate nitrogen cation 8f, which further underwent deprotonation to access the azolation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 8c. 2.2 3-Alkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones The alkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones has also been well studied in the past decades and a great deal of significant studies have been reported. Alkyl N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHP) esters 9b have been considered promising and efficient alkylating reagents, and were easily transformed into the corresponding alkyl radicals [42]. In 2018, Zhou and co-workers [43] developed a straightforward and efficient method for the alkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 9a with NHP ester 9b under sunlight or blue LED irradiation (Scheme 9 ). A broad range of 3-alkyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones were prepared in moderate yields. A possible mechanism showed that the excited-state [Ru(bpy)3]2+* [E 1/2(*RuII/RuI) = 0.77 V vs. SCE in CH3CN] was reduced by DABCO (E 1/2 DABCO = 0.6 V vs. SCE) to [Ru(bpy)3]+ along with the generation of DABCO•+. Considering the high redox activities of NHP esters 9b (E 1/2 red = −1.28 to −1.37 vs. SCE in MeCN), the reaction between [Ru(bpy)3]+ [E 1/2(RuII/RuI) = −1.33 V vs. SCE in MeCN] and NHP esters 9b via a SET process produced radical anion 9d with the formation of the ground-state of Ru(bpy)3Cl2. The splitting of the N–O bond of radical anion 9d was followed by decarboxylation to afford alkyl radical 9e, which selectively added to the C-3 position of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 9a, delivering radical 9f. Subsequently, radical 9f was oxidized by DABCO•+ to intermediate 9g, which further underwent deprotonation to give the desired products 9c. To further improve the reaction efficiency, a similar reaction was reported by the Li’s group (Scheme 10 ) [44]. A large variety of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 10a and alkyl NHP esters 10b were compatible with this transformation, and 3-alkyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 10c could be obtained in good yields. Notably, natural-amino-acid-derived NHP ester was also suitable for this protocol, generally giving rise to the aminoalkylation product 10j in 56% yield. Regrettably, product 10k containing the adamantane motif was not detected in this transformation. It was postulated that the generated alkyl radical 10l selectively added to protonated quinoxalin-2(1H)-one 10m to afford radical cation intermediate 10n, which subsequently lost a proton to produce radical 10o. Radical 10o was further oxidized by Ir(IV) to intermediate 10p along with the formation of ground-state Ir(III) for the next catalytic cycle. After deprotonation, intermediate 10p was transformed to the desired products 10c to regenerate the aromatic system. In 2019, the He’s group reported a photocatalytic decarboxylative coupling reaction for rapid access to 3-methyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 11b and 3-alkyl quinoxaline-2(1H)-ones 11c by employing a Ru(II) polypyridyl complex as the photocatalyst and eco-friendly PEG-200 as the reaction medium. (Scheme 11 ) [45]. Phenyliodine(III) dicarboxylate reagents generated in situ from PhI(OAc)2 and the corresponding carboxylic acids were the precursors, which could provide alkyl radicals. Notably, the catalytic system containing the Ru(II) polypyridyl complex and PEG-200 could be repeatedly utilized five times without an obvious decrease in catalytic activity. Furthermore, this practical method could be implemented under irradiation with sunlight with potential for scaleup. It was postulated that the reaction between PhI(OAc)2 and the excited-state Ru(II)* produced radical 11d via a SET process, which further underwent a decarboxylation procedure to afford a methyl radical (Me•). The addition of Me• to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 11a produced radical 11e, which was subsequently oxidized by Ru(III) to access cation 11f with the regeneration of Ru(II) for the next catalytic cycle. The deprotonation of cation 11f provided 3-methyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 11b. At almost the same time, a similar reaction performed in DMSO was reported by the Hu’s group [46], in which various 3-methyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 11b and 3-alkyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 11c were obtained in good yields. The high price of Ru(II)/Ir(III) polypyridyl complexes has become a point of resistance for the use of these transformations in practical applications. In 2019, Jin’s group [47] developed a metal-free route to synthesize a large variety of 3-alkylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 12c via decarboxylative coupling by reacting quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 12a with alkyl NHP esters 12b (Scheme 12 ). This reaction could effectively avoid the employment of precious Ru(II)/Ir(III) polypyridyl complexes. It is worth noting that the reaction has broad substrate applicability, and almost all primary, secondary, and tertiary NHP esters were compatible with this reaction. More importantly, adamantyl NHP ester, which has not survived under previous methods, is also applicable to this metal-free method to generate product 12k in 75% yield. Additionally, this method has been successfully put to practical use to synthesize the aldose reductase inhibitor precursor 12l in 73% yield. In 2020, the Xuan’s group [48] reported a photocatalyst-free procedure for the elegant alkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones (Scheme 13 ). A large variety of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 13a and R-DHPs 13b were compatible to access 3-arylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 13c in good yields. More importantly, some molecules containing natural isolates and drug-derived complexes were proven to be suitable substrates. Additionally, the final products for further synthetic transformations highlight the utility and practicality of this transformation. Very recently, the Wang’s group [49] reported an electrochemical decarboxylative strategy for the C-3 alkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 14a with alkyl NHP esters 14b under metal- and additive-free conditions (Scheme 14 ). Cyclic, acyclic, primary, secondary, and tertiary NHP esters all reacted smoothly in this green method, allowing the formation of a C−C bond in one step to access the desired products, demonstrating the advantage of a wide reaction scope. Moreover, NHP esters derived from valine and dehydrocholic acid were also applicable to this electrochemical decarboxylative protocol, indicating that it is a promising transformation for amino acids and natural products. Significantly, this powerful methodology could be further simplified using a 3-V battery as a power source without specialized equipment, and a 90% yield of the corresponding product could be obtained. A reasonable mechanistic pathway involving a radical process was proposed. The alkyl radical 14e generated from NHP ester 14b at the cathode via single-electron reduction and decarboxylation added to the C-3 position of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 14a to furnish radical 14f. Radical 14f then underwent a 1,2-H shift to afford carbon-centered radical 14g, which was further oxidized at the anode to give carbon cation 14h. Carbon cation 14h underwent deprotonation to produce the corresponding product 14c. Later, the same group realized the electrochemical alkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 15a with alkyl boronic acids and their derivatives 15b (Scheme 15 ) [50]. A wide range of alkylboronic acids reacted smoothly to access the desired 3-alkyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 15c in moderate to good yields. More importantly, this method could be successfully conducted using a battery as a power supply without employing a complicated DC power device. Cyclic ethers are significant motifs that are widespread in numerous biologically active natural products and pharmaceutically active compounds [51]. In 2018, Wei and co-workers [52] reported a visible light-promoted metal-free system for the coupling of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 16a with simple ethers 16b (Scheme 16 ). After screening of the reaction conditions, rose bengal (RB) was proven to be the most efficient photocatalyst for this efficient and operationally simple method. A large variety of simple ethers including cyclic and acyclic ethers were suitable substrates to produce 16c in acceptable yields. The control experiment in which TEMPO was added to the standard mixture completely suppressed this transformation, giving strong evidence for the involvement of the radical pathway. Moreover, the observed kinetic isotope effects (KIE) suggested that the cleavage of the α-C−H bond in ethers 16b was the rate-determining step. The plausible mechanism showed that a SET process between RB* and TBHP produced a tert-butyloxy radical ( t BuO•) and hydroxide anion (OH−). The reaction between the tert-butyloxy radical and ethers 16b then afforded alkoxyalkyl radical 16d, which added to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 16a to produce radical 16e. Radical intermediate 16e underwent a 1,2-H shift, followed by single-electron oxidation to access carbon cation 16g, which finally lost a proton to give 3-oxyalkylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 16c. However, an extra equivalent of the oxidant (TBHP) is essential for the above method developed by Wei’s group [52], which further limited its practical application. To overcome this drawback, an Eosin-Y-catalyzed transformation for the introduction of a cyclic ether moiety onto quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones was reported by the Suryavanshi’s group in 2019 (Scheme 17 ) [53]. The prepared products 17d could undergo hydrogenation in the presence of Pd/C to produce 17e in 94% yield or oxidative 1,3-dipolar addition with 4-methoxybenzaldehyde oxime in the presence of (diacetoxyiodo)benzene (PIDA) to afford 17f in 75% yield. Unlike in Wei’s work [52], the key intermediate alkoxyalkyl radical 17g was generated by a HAT process between ethers 17b and excited-state Eosin Y. Radical 17g added to the quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 17a, which subsequently underwent a dehydrogenative aromatization reaction to afford products 17c. The cyano groups is a privileged structural motif that is widely found in drugs and functional materials [54,55]. Recently, the ring-opening of cyclobutyl iminyl radicals has attracted wide interest because the newly generated cyano groups are valuable in organic transformations, as they can be further transformed into various functional groups [56,57]. In 2019, the Li’s group [58] reported a highly efficient and metal-free approach to synthesize 3-cyanoalkylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 18c (Scheme 18 ). Both strained oxime esters and challenging un-strained oxime esters could participate in the reaction to afford numerous products 18c in moderate to good yields. Additionally, some meaningful substrates containing important natural biological frameworks such as commercially available benzothiazole, benzoxazole, and isoquinoline are also suitable for this photocatalytic system. Stern-Volmer fluorescence-quenching experiments were further conducted, which confirmed the effective quenching of the photocatalyst by cyclobutanone oxime esters 18b. It was proposed that a SET process between excited-state Eosin Y* and cyclobutanone oxime esters 18b led to the generation of iminyl radical 18d. Subsequently, the ring-opening of iminyl radical 18d via homolytic C−C bond cleavage delivered highly reactive cyanoalkyl radical 18e, which further added to 18a to generate radical intermediate 18f. Intermediate 18f underwent a SET process, followed by deprotonation to access the final product 18c. At almost the same time, the Wang’s [59], Xu’s [60], and Yang’s [61] groups independently reported similar reactions for the synthesis of 3-cyanoalkylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones (Scheme 19 ). Compared to Wang’s [59] and Xu’s [60] works, the approach reported by the Yang’s group [61] was compatible with more structurally diverse cyclobutanone oxime esters 19b. Various N- or O-cyclobutanone oxime esters, including strained oxime esters and even un-strained oxime esters, were suitable for this transformation, giving satisfactory yields of 19c. In 2019, the Studer’s group [62] reported a photo-initiated three-component α-perfluoroalkyl-β-heteroarylation of diverse alkenes 20b with perfluoroalkyl iodides 20c and quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 20a, which allowed the synthesis of quinoxalin-2(1H)-one derivatives containing a perfluoroalkyl moiety in moderate to excellent yields (Scheme 20 ). The reaction performed well employing DBU as base and NMP as the solvent under an argon atmosphere. In particular, various alkenes with different functional groups (alcohol, ester, phosphonate, nitrile, and halo groups) and alkenes bearing heterocycles including thiophene, carbazole, coumarin, and isoindoline-1,3-dione were applicable to this transformation. In the presence of DBU, Rf-I was initially converted to Rf-radical 20e under visible light, which subsequently added to alkenes 20b to generate intermediate 20f. Afterward, intermediate 20f was further added to the C3-position of quinoxalin-2(1H)-one 20a to deliver aminyl radical 20g, which further underwent deprotonation and a SET process to furnish the final products 20d. Very recently, the Wei’s group [63] developed a similar three-component reaction by employing Langlois reagent (CF3SO2Na) as a trifluoromethyl radical precursor (Scheme 21 ). This metal-free protocol enables the synthesis of the desired products 21d in moderate to good yields and shows wide reaction scope and good functional group tolerance. 2.3 3-Fluoroalkylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones The introduction of fluorine-containing functional groups into organic molecules can greatly affect their physical and chemical properties, leading to increased lipophilicity, enhanced membrane permeability, improved biological activity, and so on [64]. In this context, the construction of fluoroalkylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones through photochemical and electrochemical redox strategies has been well developed. Through these elegant methods, the trifluoromethylation, difluoromethylation, and perfluoromethylation of quinoxaline have been successfully achieved. In 2019, Zeng et al. [65] employed Baran reagent (Zn(SO2CF3)2) as the trifluoromethylation reagent to realize the electrocatalytic synthesis of trifluoroalkylated quinoxaline-2-ones 22c (Scheme 22 ). Cyclic voltammetric analysis showed that the in situ formation of sulfonyl hypobromite (CF3SO2Br) was the key to improve the reaction efficiency over direct electrolysis by regulating and controlling the generation of trifluoromethyl radical 22e at low concentration. The proposed mechanism showed that bromide was oxidized to molecular Br2 at the anode, which subsequently reacted with Zn(CF3SO2)2 to produce sulfonyl hypobromite 22d or sulfonyl bromide 22d’. Sulfonyl bromide 22d’ then underwent a cathodic reduction or a homolytic cleavage, followed by the release of SO2 to form trifluoromethyl radical 22e. Next, the addition of trifluoromethyl radical 22e to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 22a gave radical 22f, which was further oxidized at the anode to the desired products 22c. This elegant protocol provided a powerful synthetic method to access trifluoroalkylated quinoxaline-2-ones 22c. However, this electrochemical synthesis failed to obtain the desired products in high yields. To further improve the reaction efficiency, the Jin’s group [66] disclosed a photocatalyst-free method for the trifluoromethylation of quinoxalin-2-ones under visible-light irradiation in 2019 (Scheme 23 ). This environment friendly strategy utilized Langlois reagent (CF3SO2Na) as a trifluoromethyl radical precursor and air as an oxidant to access a variety of 3-trifluoromethyl quinoxalin-2-ones 23c. Mechanism studies proved the formation of superoxide radical anions (O2 •−) and excited-state singlet oxygen (1O2) through ESR experiments. Presumably, substrates 23a or products 23c could be effectively activated by visible light to form the excited states 23a* or 23c*, which could promote the production of singlet 1O2 with the regeneration of the ground-state 23a or 23c for the next cycle. After that, CF3SO2Na was oxidized by the highly active 1O2 via a SET process, followed by the release of SO2 to form a trifluoromethyl radical, which further underwent radical addition reaction with quinoxaline-2-ones 23a to access intermediate 23e. Finally, intermediate 23e underwent hydrogen atom abstraction by O2 •− to produce the desired products 23c. Simultaneously, the Duan’s group [67] reported a visible-light promoted protocol for the C-3 perfluoroalkylation of quinoxalin-2-ones 24a with sodium perfluoroalkanesulfinates 24b (Scheme 24 ). By employing sodium perfluoroalkanesulfinates 24b as the fluoroalkylation reagents, Eosin Y as a photocatalyst, and oxygen as an oxidant, a variety of perfluoroalkylated quinoxalin-2-ones 24c were obtained in satisfactory yields. Diverse sodium perfluoroalkanesulfinates 24b, including CF3SO2Na, C4F9SO2Na, C6F13SO2Na, C8F17SO2Na, and C2H5O2CCF2SO2Na could perform well in this transformation. Furthermore, gram-scale synthesis was performed to reveal the scalability of this method, and five products were prepared in 8 mmol scale without an obvious decrease in the yield. The trifluoromethylated quinoxalinone could be further transformed into quinoxaline 24d, which was a suitable substrate for Suzuki coupling reaction to access 24e. Additionally, trifluoromethylated quinoxalinone could also be reduced by LiAlH4, leading to the formation of 24f in 91% yield. Mechanism studies showed that the excited state of the photocatalyst (Eosin Y*) was effectively quenched by sodium perfluoroalkanesulfinates 24b via a SET process to afford trifluoromethyl radical 24g, which further reacted with quinoxalin-2-ones 24a to deliver radical 24h. Moreover, the reaction between Eosin Y•− and O2 produced O2 •−. Radical 24h further underwent a 1,2-H shift to afford radical 24i. Subsequently, radical 24i underwent a SET process with O2 •−, followed by deprotonation to access products 24c. Difluoroalkyl bromides have been considered as effective difluoroalkylation reagents that could be easily reduced to difluoroalkyl radicals by an excited photocatalyst. In 2019, Jin et al. [68] realized the C-3 difluoroalkylation of quinoxalin-2-ones 25a using difluoroalkyl bromides 25b as the precursor of difluoroalkyl radicals (Scheme 25 ). It is worth noting that a catalytic amount of diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) was the key for the successful transformation. This simple strategy was easily scaled up to provide CF2COOEt-substituted quinoxaline-2-one 25d in 75% yield at a 5 mmol scale, which could be further converted to CF2H-substituted quinoxaline-2-one 25e in high yield (90%). In the mechanism, BrCF2COR was reduced by Ir(III)* to generate difluoromethyl radical •CF2COR with the generation of Ir(IV). The Ir(IV) could be further reduced by DIPEA to regenerate Ir(ppy)3 with DIPEA•+. The regioselective addition of •CF2COR to quinoxalin-2-ones 25a produced radical intermediate 25g, which could be transformed into the final product 25c via a HAT process with DIPEA•+. Among the various fluoroalkyl groups, benzylic difluoromethylene groups (ArCF2) possess unique stability and isosteric properties as a carbonyl group or an ethereal oxygen atom, and they have attracted increasing attention in medicinal chemistry [69–71]. Very recently, the Wang’s group [72] developed the visible-light-induced difluoroarylmethylation of quinoxalin-2-ones 26a with ArCF2COOK 26b, which could avoid the need for excessive oxidant and high temperature (Scheme 26 ). By employing water as a green solvent, a large variety of C-3 difluoroarylmethylated quinoxalin-2-ones 26c were isolated in good yields. An interesting photocatalyst-free mechanism showed that K2S2O8 was initially cleaved into SO4 •− under irradiation by blue LEDs, which further reacted with 26d to form PhCF2 • (26e). PhCF2 • (26e) completed the radical addition process to generate a new radical intermediate 26f. Radical intermediate 26f subsequently underwent single-electron oxidation and deprotonation to give 26g. The difluoromethyl functional group (–CF2H) is a lipophilic hydrogen bond donor that has been considered as a feasible alternative to traditional hydrogen bond donors such as thiol (SH), hydroxy (OH), amino (NH2), amide (CONH2), carbinol (CH2OH), and hydroxamic acid (CONHOH) groups in terms of cell membrane permeability, lipophilicity, and metabolic stability [73]. The introduction of the difluoromethyl functional group into novel scaffolds would provide improved biological activity with potential value in drug development. Very recently, Li et al. [74] introduced the difluoromethyl functional group (–CF2H) into quinoxalin-2-ones 27a using environment friendly CF2HSO2Na (27b) as the difluoromethylation reagent under mild photocatalytic conditions (Scheme 27 ). In this reaction, oxygen (from air) was used as an oxidant and RB was employed as a metal-free photocatalyst. Under irradiation by green light, this novel and powerful transformation could effectively avoid the utilization of expensive and toxic fluorine reagents and transition metal reagents to afford difluoromethylated quinoxaline-2-ones 27c and showed excellent functional group compatibility. Importantly, this efficient route could be performed successfully under irradiation by sunlight, demonstrating the synthetic potential of this methodology. The results of radical trapping experiments indicated the involvement of •CF2H in this reaction pathway. The results of an in situ 1H NMR experiment indicated the conversion of O2 into H2O rather than H2O2. The mechanism study showed that the reaction between excited-state RB* (E red = 0.99 V vs. SCE) and CF2HSO2Na (E = 0.59 V vs. SCE) generated •CF2H and RB•−. RB•− was further oxidized by O2 to give ground state RB and O2 •−. After a similar radical addition and 1,2-H shift, radical 27f was formed, which underwent a HAT process with O2 •− to provide the final products 27c. 2.4 3-Amination/amidation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones The construction of the C–N bonds of aromatic compounds is of great importance and has attracted increasing interest from chemists [75]. Since the first report of the introduction of the amino group in a controlled manner by Ullmann and Goldberg in the 1900s, the rapid emergence of transition-metal-catalyzed strategies has led to considerable progress [76]. However, the use of transition metals, ligand or directing groups, and thermal conditions are inevitable in these transformations. In recent years, the rapid development of photocatalysis and electrocatalysis has provided a sustainable alternative to assemble C–N bonds predictably and selectively. In 2018, Wei and co-workers [77] reported the photocatalytic amination of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 28a with aliphatic amines 28b employing cheap Eosin Y as the photocatalyst in the absence of any external oxidant (Scheme 28 ). Both secondary and even primary aliphatic amines were suitable for this elegant transformation, which allowed the direct formation of 3-aminoquinoxalin-2-(1H)-ones 28c in ambient conditions with moderate to good yields. Regrettably, arylamines such as aniline and N-methylaniline were incompatible with the reaction, and no desired products were detected. Exploration of the mechanism including radical trapping and ESR experiments indicated that a nitrogen radical was involved in the reaction process. Moreover, control experiments under N2 gave only a trace amount of the desired product, suggesting the essential role of O2 in this transformation. As shown, a SET process between the excited-state Eosin Y* and aliphatic amines 28b produced radical cation 28d and Eosin Y•−. Eosin Y•− could be oxidized by O2 to regenerate ground-state Eosin Y and O2 •−, which further reacted with radical cation 28d to access the key N-centered radical 28e. After sequential similar radical addition, single-electron oxidation, and deprotonation, the desired products 28c were generated. Almost simultaneously, the Zeng’s group [78] developed an electrochemical method to achieve the amination of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 29a in 2019 (Scheme 29 ). All five-, six-, and seven-membered cyclic amines and even azoles were applicable to give the desired products in moderate to good yields. When piperazine was employed as the amination reagent, substrates with attached electron-withdrawing groups showed better reactivities, delivering a higher yield than those bearing electron-donating groups. Compared to Wei’s method [77], the reaction of primary aliphatic amines did not proceed smoothly. Similarly, aromatic anilines were also not suitable substrates, which might have undergone polymerization to turn the reaction mixture black quickly. A possible mechanism involving a nucleophilic addition (an ionic mechanism) and a radical pathway was proposed. The reaction of amines 29b and the protonated quinoxaline-2(1H)-one 29d afforded 29e, which underwent anodic oxidation and deprotonation to access products 29c (pathway 1). Additionally, amines 29b underwent anodic oxidation to produce nitrogen radical 29f, which further added to the protonated quinoxaline-2(1H)-one 29d, followed by anodic oxidation and deprotonation to access the corresponding products 29c (pathway 2). Simultaneously, the proton was reduced at the cathode to release molecular hydrogen. The control experiments indicated that the radical pathway (pathway 2) might be predominant for this electrochemical protocol. The significance of amides emerges from their extensive presence in fertilizers, fabrics, proteins, insecticides, plastics, and drugs. In 2019, the He’s group [79] developed a straightforward and metal-free approach to access N-acylated 3-aminoquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 30c (Scheme 30 ). Various aryl amides bearing different electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups were compatible with the current amidation reaction, leading to the formation of N-acylated 3-aminoquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 30c in satisfactory yield without obvious electronic or steric effects. Moreover, both straight-chain aliphatic amides and bulky cycloalkyl amides were suitable substrates, allowing the generation of the expected products in good yields. Exploration of the mechanism provided strong evidence regarding the important role of oxygen and the existence of a radical pathway. Additionally, the fluorescence quenching experiment indicated that a SET process between the excited-state Rhodamine B* and quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 30a might exist to produce radical cation 30d. Nucleophilic addition of amides 30b to radical cation 30d generates intermediate 30e, which could be further oxidized by O2 •− to 30c with H2O2. Very recently, the Yang’s group [80] developed O-perhalopyridin-4-yl hydroxylamines 31b as novel amidyl-radical precursors for the amination of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones under photocatalyst-free conditions (Scheme 31 ). The novel amidyl-radical precursors 31b could be directly prepared in a single synthetic step from inexpensive commercially available starting materials, and various 3-aminoquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones could be obtained in satisfactory yields. Mechanistic studies suggested that electron donor-acceptor (EDA) complexes 31d between quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 31a and O-perhalopyridin-4-yl hydroxylamines 31b were formed, which underwent a SET process to produce the radical ion pair 31e. Then, radical cation 31f and amidyl radical 31g were formed from radical ion pair 31e, which further underwent radical cross-coupling reaction to access intermediate 31h. Finally, intermediate 31h regenerated the aromatic system to give 31c by deprotonation. 2.5 3-Phosphorylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones The installation of phosphine groups into organic molecules is of significant importance, and is carried out to provide enhanced bioavailability and inherent optical and electronic properties [81,82]. In 2018, a photoredox protocol for the phosphorylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 32a with diphenylphosphine oxide 32b was reported by the Kim group (Scheme 32 ) [83]. This strategy provides a powerful method to synthesize 3-phosphorylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 32c. As shown, diphenylphosphine oxide 32b usually exists in rapid equilibrium with phosphinous acid 32b’, which underwent single-electron oxidation with Eosin B* to access radical cation 32e and Eosin B•−. Radical cation 32e subsequently lost a proton to afford phosphinoyl radical 32f, which underwent an addition with quinoxalin-2(1H)-one 32a to generate 32g. After single-electron oxidation and deprotonation, 32c was finally formed. Very recently, a photocatalyst-free method for the phosphorylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones under aerobic metal-free conditions was developed by the Subbarayappa group (Scheme 33 ) [84]. Various dialkyl H-phosphonates 33b were suitable for this transformation, providing an elegant method for the synthesis of phosphonated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. The phosphinoyl radical was produced by a SET process between dialkyl H-phosphonates 33b and O2. In 2019, the group of Zeng [85] developed an electrochemical approach for the phosphorylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones (Scheme 34 ). The procedure was conducted in an undivided cell and allowed the synthesis of various 3-phosphonated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones in moderate to excellent yields. Notably, this protocol was compatible with various diarylphosphine oxides and dialkyl H-phosphonates. In the mechanism, quinoxaline-2(1H)-ones 34a was initially oxidized at the anode to intermediate 34d, which further reacted with 34b’ to form phosphinoyl radical 34e with the reformation of 34a due to the low oxidation potential gap. Subsequently, phosphinoyl radical 34e attacked the C=N bond of the protonated quinoxaline-2(1H)-one 34f to produce 34g, which further underwent anodic oxidation and deprotonation to afford the desired products 34c. At almost at the same time, the Wang group developed a similar method to construct phosphorylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 35c by utilizing graphite electrodes as the anode and a platinum plate as the cathode (Scheme 35 ) [86]. A variety of substituted quinolin-2(1H)-ones 35a reacted smoothly with diarylphosphine oxides 35b to access 35c in good to excellent yield. Additionally, this straightforward method was also suitable to introduce the pyrrole skeleton into quinolin-2(1H)-ones 35a to access pyrrole-functionalized quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 35e in good yields. 2.6 3-Acylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones As an important process for biological and chemical applications, the acylation reaction has always been a research hotspot, and has been attracting increasing interest from synthetic chemists [87,88]. The well-known Friedel-Crafts reactions are usually performed under strictly anhydrous conditions with the production of large amounts of waste salts. Recently, acyl- (or related) radical-initiated organic transformations have been extensively developed, and have been considered as an appealing alternative approach for the introduction of acyl groups [89]. Very recently, Xuan et al. [90] reported a photocatalyst-free protocol for the synthesis of 3‐acyl quinoxalin‐2(1H)-ones 36c (Scheme 36 ). Significantly, quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones containing natural molecule skeletons were applicable to this elegant protocol, demonstrating the practicality of this efficient and powerful method. The mechanism showed that the reaction between α-oxo-carboxylic acids 36b and pinene-derived iminodiacetic acid (PIDA) generated phenyliodine(III) dicarboxylate reagents in-situ, which were the real acylation reagents and could effectively produce the key acyl radicals for this transformation. Almost simultaneously, the He’s group [87,88] reported the photosynthetic 3-acylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones under metal-, strong-oxidant- and external-photocatalyst-free conditions. Mechanism studies showed that substrates 37a were excited to the excited species 37a* under irradiation by LED light (400–405 nm), which subsequently reacted with ground-state triplet oxygen 3O2 via an energy transfer (ET) process to afford active excited-state singlet oxygen 1O2 with the regeneration of substrates 37a. A hydrogen-atom-transfer (HAT) process between active 1O2 and phenylglyoxylic acid 37b produced a hydroperoxy radical (HO2 •) and aroyl radicals 37d, which added to substrates 37a to afford carbon-centered radical 37e. Next, radical 37e underwent a 1,2-H shift to generate nitrogen-centered radical 37f, which was further oxidized by HO2 •, followed by deprotonation to afford 3-acyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 37c. The desired products could also serve as photocatalysts in this transformation. Scheme 37 Strong-oxidant-free method for producing 3-acyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. Very recently, the Zhao’s group [91] utilized Eosin Y as a direct hydrogen-atom-transfer photocatalyst for the preparation of 3-acyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 38c by employing readily available aldehydes 38b as the acyl radical precursors (Scheme 38 ). Initially, the neutral Eosin Y could be obtained by the reaction of Na2-Eosin Y and NH4 +, which could then absorb the energy of visible light to give the excited-state Eosin Y*. Afterward, the acyl radical was generated via a HAT process between aldehydes 38b and Eosin Y*. After similar radical addition and oxidation, the desired products could be obtained. The oxidation reaction of Eosin Y-H by S2O8 2− would lead to the formation of the neutral Eosin Y for the next cycle. Very recently, the Lee’s group [92] reported an atmosphere-controlled protocol for the selective preparation of hydroxyl- and acyl-containing quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones under metal-free conditions (Scheme 39 ). Among them, hydroxyl-containing quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 39c exhibited excellent fluorescence for use as potent fluorophores. Fluorescence quenching experiments showed that the luminescence of Acr+MesClO4 − was efficiently quenched by quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 39a, implying a possible SET process between the excited photocatalyst and quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 39a to produce aminyl cation radical 39e. Under an Ar atmosphere (path a), aminyl cation radical 39e reacted with α-oxocarboxylic acids 39b to afford acyl radical 39f, which added to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 39a to form radical 39g. Reduction of radical 39g’ led to the formation of intermediate 39h, which subsequently underwent a protonation process to provide hydroxyl-containing quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 39c. Under an air atmosphere (path b), 1O2 was formed by Acr+MesClO4 −, which could react with α-oxocarboxylic acids 39b to afford acyl radical 39f. After a similar radical addition and a 1,2-H shift process, radical 39i was produced, which was further oxidized to cationic intermediate 39j. Finally, the acyl-containing quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 39d were obtained by the deprotonation of intermediate 39j. 2.7 3-Alkoxylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones Ethers are privileged structural motifs that are widely present in natural products, bioactive molecules, drugs, and functional materials [93]. In 2020, the He’s group [22] developed a photocatalytic alkoxylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 40a with alcohols 40b (Scheme 40 ). This reaction proceeded smoothly in CH3CN utilizing air as a green oxidant under irradiation by blue light, providing a direct synthetic method for 3-alkoxyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 40c. Under the optimized conditions, a wide array of alcohols with different carbon-chain lengths, isomeric structures, and various functional groups were compatible with this eco-friendly method. Both straight-chain alkyl alcohols and bulky cycloalkyl alcohols were suitable substrates for this transformation. Meaningfully, complex natural alcohols, such as L-menthol and borneol, reacted smoothly to obtain the desired products in 72% and 77% isolated yields, respectively. Based on radical trapping experiments, a reasonable mechanism involving a radical process was presented. Radical cation 40d, which was generated by a SET process between the excited-state photocatalyst and quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 40a, could be attacked by alcohols 40b to produce radical 40e. Radical 40e further underwent single-electron oxidation by O2 to afford the desired products 40c. The same work was also reported by the Li’s group [94], in which the alkoxylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones could be achieved in EtOH. Very recently, the Yu’s group [95] developed an efficient and environmentally friendly electrochemical approach to access a large variety of C3-alkoxylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 41c (Scheme 41 ). Various alcohols 41b including primary alcohols from methanol to cyclopropylmethanol, acyclic secondary alcohols, and cyclopentanol were applicable to this elegant protocol. However, tert-butanol was not a suitable substrate to produce the corresponding product, which might be due to the bulky steric hindrance. Significantly, deuterated methanol was compatible with this transformation to provide a simple method to form deuterated alkoxylated quinoxalinone in 83% yield, demonstrating the promising potential of this approach for the introduction of deuterium atoms into drug candidates. In the proposed mechanism, quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 41a generated radical cation intermediate 41d via SET oxidation at the anode, which then underwent nucleophilic attack to deliver 41e. Finally, further anodic oxidation and deprotonation of 41e occurred to furnish the corresponding product 41c. Recently, Xia et al. [96] reported a metal-free manner to access fluoroalkoxylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 42c through the Eosin-Y-catalyzed C–H functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 42a with readily available fluoroalkyl alcohols 42b under visible-light irradiation (Scheme 42 ). This meaningful approach employed oxygen as a green oxidant to make this strategy more in accord with the concept of green chemistry. It is worth mentioning that the product 42d could be transformed into the N-containing bidentate ligand 42e in 50% yield. Unfortunately, this protocol also has certain limitations; for example, sterically hindered longer-chain and bulky fluoroalkyl alcohols including octafluoropentyl alcohol, nonafluoro-tert-butanol, and hexafluoroisopropanol could not participate in the transformation to access the desired products. The reasonable mechanism showed that a SET process occurred between Eosin Y* and quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 42a to generate the anion radical Eosin Y•− and intermediate 42f. The intermediate 42f was then reacted with fluoroalkyl alcohols 42b to produce the intermediate 42g. Meanwhile, Eosin Y•− was oxidized by O2 to give ground-state Eosin Y and O2 •−. Finally, 42g underwent an oxidation and proton transfer process to obtain the target product 42c along with the formation of H2O2, which was confirmed by a starch potassium iodide test paper. 2.8 3-Thiolation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones Due to the promising pharmaceutical value of aromatic sulfur compounds, there is still a great need for the development of sustainable methods to prepare aromatic sulfur compounds [97–99]. Recently, Pan and co-workers [100] reported a visible-light-initiated metal- and additive-free approach for the preparation of 3-thiolated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 43c by reacting quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 43a with thiols 43b (Scheme 43 ). This method features the merits of wide substrate scope, mild reaction conditions, and good functional group tolerance. Substrates with electron-deficient and electron-rich substituents in both thiols 43b and quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 43a were well tolerated, leading to the formation of a C–S bond in one step to access the desired products 43c. Radical trapping experiments suggested that this transformation might be carried out through a radical pathway. Initially, the thiols were partially converted into thiol anions and H+. The thiol anions 43d were oxidized by O2 in air to generate thiyl radicals 43e under irradiation by blue LED light. Subsequently, the thiyl radicals 43e could smoothly react with the quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones to produce radical 43f. Finally, product 43c was produced after a 1,2-hydrogen shift, oxidation and deprotonation. Almost simultaneously, other elegant photocatalytic approaches for the thiolation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones were developed by He’s [101] and Li’s [102] groups (Scheme 44 ). In the method developed by He’s group, various thiols with sterically demanding branched chains or long aliphatic chains were suitable for this photocatalytic transformation to produce products 44c in good yields. Additionally, linear thiols with terminal alkenyl groups, furan, ester, or phenyl ring on the chain were also applicable to this approach, demonstrating good functional group tolerance. Importantly, aryl thiols such as benzenethiol could also react smoothly to furnish the thiolation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. In Li’s method, aryl thiols were not a suitable substrate. However, this method could be applied to the synthesis of 3-alkoxyl quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones, providing a facile and practical protocol for the (thio)etherification of quinoxalinones 44e. Later, an electrochemical method for the 3-thiolation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones was developed by the Li’s group (Scheme 45 ) [103]. Both aliphatic and aryl thiols were suitable substrates, which allowed the formation of C–S bonds in an undivided cell equipped with platinum as both the anode and the cathode to access the 3-thiolated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 45c in good yields. 2.9 3-Silylation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones Very recently, the Sun’s group [104] reported the direct 3-silylation of quinoxalinones under transition metal- and external-oxidant-free conditions (Scheme 46 ). Various quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 46a bearing electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups could react with tert-butyldimethylsilane, leading to the formation of 3-silylated quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 46c in moderate to good yields. A kinetic isotope effect experiment indicated that the cleavage of Si–H may not be the kinetically rate-determining step in this photocatalytic transformation. Additionally, the desired product could be transformed into 1-methyl-1,4-dihydroquinoxaline-2,3-dione (46d) in 53% yield, showing the synthetic application of this method. 2.10 Annulation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones Despite the great achievements that have been made in the C3-functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones, the annulation of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones to related poly-fused heterocycles has rarely been reported. In 2020, Yu’s group [105] reported an efficient and powerful method for the preparation of tetrahydroimidazo-[1,5-a]quinoxalin-4(5H)-ones 47c (Scheme 47 ). In the presence of CsPbBr3, a large variety of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 47a with various N-aryl glycines 47b could react smoothly in a green solvent, allowing the formation of one C–C and two C–N bonds in one step to access 47c in moderate to good yields. The mechanism showed that a SET process from N-phenyl glycines 47b to a hole (h+) produced phenylaminomethyl radical 47d, which added to quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 47a to afford radical 47e. Afterward, the coupling of radical 47e and phenylaminomethyl radical 47d gave the intermediate 47f, which subsequently underwent protonation to afford 47g. Intermediate 47g lost a good leaving group, an aniline molecule, to form intermediate 47i, which underwent an intramolecular nucleophilic attack, followed by deprotonation to furnish 47c. Considering the toxicity of lead in CsPbBr3, a metal-free protocol for the synthesis of tetrahydroimidazo-[1,5-a]quinoxalin-4(5H)-ones 48c in the presence of graphene-like carbon nitride (g-C3N4) was developed (Scheme 48 ) [106]. It should be noted that when the same reaction was carried out in DMSO/H2O, dihydroquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones 48d were selectively generated in moderate yields. The selectivity may be caused by the difference in the solubility of oxygen in the different solvents. The heterogeneous photocatalyst g-C3N4 could be recovered by simple centrifugation and reused at least five times with negligible impact on the catalytic activity. 3 Summary and outlook The direct functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones has attracted increasing interest from synthetic chemists because of their broad range of promising prospects in medicinal chemistry and functional materials. In this review, we have presented an overview of the reported photo-/electrocatalytic functionalizations of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones, mainly those reported in recent years. Various carbon-centered and heteroatom-centered radicals could be successfully produced under mild reaction conditions, and further added to the C-3 position of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones to develop efficient approaches for the post-synthetic modification of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones to broaden the versatility of valuable N-heterocycles. Some gentle methods have been applied for the synthesis of molecules with significant biological activities, such as aldose reductase (ALR2) inhibitor [102], aldose reductase inhibitor precursor [47], and synthetically valuable chlorinated quinoxaline [62]. Moreover, some meaningful functional groups commonly found in drugs, such as trifluoromethyl and difluoromethyl groups, could also be smoothly introduced into the quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. Regrettably, systematic studies have not yet been carried out to clarify their biological activities. The exploration of novel synthetic methodologies for the preparation of structurally diverse quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones to meet the requirements of drug activity and investigation of the related therapeutic activities is still highly desired. Additionally, some functionalized quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones showed excellent luminescence [92], and might be potential fluorophores for promising applications in functional materials. Despite these outstanding achievements, photocatalysts are generally homogeneous catalysts, which are difficult to recycle and reuse. The development of a novel heterogeneous photocatalyst to realize the direct functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones is highly desired. In addition, different functionalized quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones could be excited by visible light to act as the photocatalyst, which thus achieved the formation of carbon–carbon or carbon–heteroatom bonds under photocatalyst-free conditions. Electrochemistry offers a powerful method to provide highly oxidizing and reducing potentials that can exceed the limitations of chemical reductants and oxidants. The combination of electrochemistry and photochemistry might enable reactions with unforeseen reactivity and selectivity that are difficult or impossible through electrochemistry or photochemistry. We hope that this review will facilitate further research focused on photoelectrocatalysis with high efficiency and regioselectivity, which could provide sustainable alternative methods for the preparation of diversely functionalized quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones with promising applications in materials science and pharmaceutical chemistry. coredata.dc:description: The photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones has emerged as a promising and powerful approach for post-synthetic modification of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones. This review provides an overview of recent developments in photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones including arylation, alkylation, fluoroalkylation, amination, phosphorylation, acylation, alkoxylation, thiolation, silylation, and annulation. The reaction scope and the related mechanism are also well discussed.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Photo-/electrocatalytic functionalization of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones
